title: Personal Summary
text: Iâ€™m Yonas Atinafu, an AI and machine learning researcher and engineer focused on trustworthy and practical AI systems. Iâ€™m currently an MMath Computer Science student at the University of Waterloo (AI group), supervised by Professor Robin Cohen and co-supervised by Professor Jamal Bentahar. My work sits at the intersection of responsible AI, agentic systems, and applied machine learning, with strong engineering depth across ML systems, evaluation, and deployment. I care about building AI that is reliable under real constraints: limited compute, noisy labels, shifting distributions, and the need for transparent user control. Core strengths Machine learning research and experimentation: rigorous evaluation, ablations, failure analysis. ML engineering: end-to-end pipelines, reproducible experiments, deployment-oriented thinking. ML systems mindset: latency/throughput tradeoffs, inference constraints, pragmatic optimization. Communication: turning research into clear artifacts (papers, slides, demos) and production-ready code. Selected projects and research PixLift (ACM COMPASS 2025 submission): A Chromium-based approach to reducing web data usage by requesting smaller images and upscaling on-device using efficient super-resolution, trading bandwidth for compute. EEG-based neurohaptics / haptic decoding: Graph-based and deep learning approaches to decoding perceptual experience from EEG, with strong emphasis on evaluation reliability (e.g., label quality, LOSO generalization). Agentic and trustworthy AI directions: Interest in evaluation integrity, reliable tool use, and systems that remain dependable in messy real-world settings. Background I completed my undergraduate studies at NYU Abu Dhabi. Iâ€™ve worked as a research assistant across multiple labs, building and evaluating ML models and systems, and translating research prototypes into usable tools. What Iâ€™m looking for Roles and collaborations where I can combine research-level thinking with engineering execution: ML engineer, applied scientist, AI engineer, ML systems, or trustworthy/agentic AI work. If you want to collaborate, the best way is to reach out by email with a short note on what youâ€™re building and what you need.

title: Yonas Atinafu | Papers
text: My Publications PixLift: Accelerating Web Browsing via AI Upscaling Abstract: Accessing the internet in regions with expensive data plans and limited connectivity poses significant challenges, restricting information access and economic growth. Images, as a major contributor to webpage sizes, exacerbate this issue, despite advances in compression formats like WebP and AVIF. The continued growth of complex and curated web content, coupled with suboptimal optimization practices in many regions, has prevented meaningful reductions in web page sizes. This paper introduces PixLift, a novel solution to reduce webpage sizes by downscaling their images during transmission and leveraging AI models on user devices to upscale them. By trading computational resources for bandwidth, PixLift enables more affordable and inclusive web access. We address key challenges, including the feasibility of scaled image requests on popular websites, the implementation of PixLift as a browser extension, and its impact on user experience. Through the analysis of 71.4k webpages, evaluations of three mainstream upscaling models, and a user study, we demonstrate PixLiftâ€™s ability to significantly reduce data usage without compromising image quality, fostering a more equitable internet. Conference: COMPASS '25: Proceedings of the ACM SIGCAS/SIGCHI Conference on Computing and Sustainable Societies Year: 2025 Citations: 0 Read Paper

title: Yonas Atinafu | Projects
text: Open Source Projects Machine Learning LoRA_SFT Fine-tuned the 135M-parameter SmolLM model using LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) for creative text generation. Conducted ablations on LoRA rank and base model (SmolLM vs GPT-2) using TRL and PEFT frameworks. Achieved a perplexity drop from 1.455 to 1.238 with only ~18 minutes of training on a T4 GPU. Includes visualizations of training curves, ablation comparisons, and generated samples. Python LoRA Fine-Tuning Transformer Hugging Face Machine Learning Natural Language Processing Code Production RAG Pipeline A production-ready, fully local RAG system: ingests PDFs into a FAISS inner-product index, serves retrieval via FastAPI, and generates cited answers with Flan-T5. Includes a minimal web UI, JSON endpoints (/search, /query), adjustable top_k/score_threshold, and pluggable device selection (CPU/MPS/CUDA). Python RAG FAISS FastAPI Flan-T5 NLP Information Retrieval Code ML Models for Mutation Impact Analysis This project involves building machine learning models like CNN, GRU, Random Forest, and SVM to analyze the impact of mutations in genetic data. The models are trained using a combination of SMOTE and RandomUnderSampler for handling imbalanced data and feature engineering techniques tailored for mutation data. Python Bioinformatics Machine-Learning Deep-Learning CNN GRU Random-Forest SVM Code Cancer Classification Using Gene Expression Data A project focused on classifying different types of cancer using gene expression data. The classification models used include SVM, Random Forest, and CNN, with feature engineering and data preprocessing steps tailored for gene expression datasets. By treating EEG channels as nodes in a graph, GNNs can capture the complex relationships between different brain regions, offering a powerful approach for EEG-based tasks. The model is designed to capture both temporal and spatial features from the EEG data. The CNN extracts spatial features while the Transformer model handles sequential dependencies, providing a robust solution for EEG signal analysis. Python AI Travel GPT-4 Web-Application Travel-Planner Code Misc Projects Decaf Bytecode VM Decaf is a compact language compiler and virtual machine built entirely in Python. It includes a hand-written lexer, Pratt parser, semantic resolver, and a bytecode compiler targeting a lightweight stack-based VM. The toolchain supports lexical scoping, immutability rules, function calls, disassembly tooling, and a CLI for compiling, executing, and tracing bytecode programs.
